description.narrative:
Det andra året av implementeringen av projektet "Joint Project Integrated Response to Violence against Women and Girls" är nu igång. Vid det årliga granskningsmötet, som hölls i oktober, diskuterades den första framgångsrapporten för projektet med alla partnerorganisationer och institutioner: FN och Serbiska ministerier. Alla parter var överens om att de framsteg som gjorts i de flesta av interventionsområdena var i linje med projektdokumentet och resultatmatrisen (RBM). Partnerinstitutionerna presenterade konkreta uppgifter (antal fall, utbildning, yrkesverksamma som ingår i projektverksamheten ...) men hänvisade också till den största förändringen som inträffade under det första året av genomförandet: antagandet av den nya lagen om våld i hemmet i november 2016. Lagen, som började gälla i juni 2017, erbjuder många innovativa lösningar, men föreskriver också mycket snävare tidsfrister för svar från berörda institutioner. Inom ramarna för projektet har man försökt bemöta några av de omedelbara brister som uppkommit och tillhandahållit flera pilotprogram, men behoven är mycket större. Utöver de redan deltagande institutionerna uttryckte serbiska justitie- och inrikesministeriet intresse för att ingå i projektverksamheten (deras företrädare var närvarande vid årsmötet).
Med utgångspunkt i det befintliga problemet (68 kvinnor mördade under de senaste två åren; 17 000 anmälningar för VaW från juni 2017), behovet av bistånd, (som nu är större än någonsin efter införandet av den nya lagen) samt ett starkt intresse från lokala partners har UNDP lämnat in en begäran om ytterligare finansiering av det pågående projektet. Begäran om tilläggsfinansiering uppgår till 7 580 670 kronor. Med denna begäran ber UNDP och dess partners Sida att godkänna en förlängning av aktivitetsperioden för projektet för ytterligare sex månader.
Efter att ha analyserat de framsteg som projektets uppnått hittills, diskuterat och bedömt situationen relaterad till VaW och det nya rättsliga sammanhanget, drar Sida slutsatsen att förslaget till kostnadsutbyggnad av projektet är väl förberett och korrekt motiverat. Vi bedömer att förslaget är relevant för att uppnå resultat 12 i vår strategi samt Sveriges mål att främja kvinnors rättigheter och jämställdhet. Baserat på dessa bedömningar föreslår vi att ett beslut om att bevilja kostnadsförlängning för "Joint Project Integrated Response to Violence Against Women and Girls" i Serbien är i linje med förslaget från UNDP.

The overall objective of the project is further development of social and institutional environment that will contribute to zero tolerance and eradication of violence against women in Serbia. The project will work towards changing normative framework, institutional practices and behaviors pertaining to violence against women and girls at state, community and individual levels.

Gender sensitive social and normative environment established through implementation of international and national commitments in the field of preventing and combating violence against women and girls. The specific purpose of the project is to further improve legal and policy frameworks, strengthen prevention system and assistance mechanisms for survivors of violence and improve access to effective protection from violence through sustainable delivery of general and specialist services.

sector.narrative: Ending violence against women and girls

tag.narrative: 5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

description.narrative: A gender-sensitive social and normative environment established through the implementation of international and national commitments in the field of preventing and combating violence against women and children: - Around 450 women and men Members of Parliament (MPs) and Local MPs from 90 Serbian municipalities were informed on and actively discussed the key achievements, gaps and challenges in the implementation of the Istanbul Convention and national legislation on preventing domestic violence. - The Coordination Body for Gender Equality successfully coordinated the first national evaluation process on the implementation of the Istanbul Convention. The process, which included 260 institutions and organizations at the national, provincial and local levels, confirms the mobilization of Serbian government to fulfil international commitments on combating violence against women and girls. - The number of health institutions that reported violence against children grew from 32 to 49 and the number of children reported to be victims of violence increased from 649 to 889. Although the share of boys and girls is equal, physical violence dominated among boys, victims of emotional violence were equally boys and girls, while all other forms (sexual, digital, witness of domestic violence) were more frequently reported among girls. General and specialist service providers capacitated to effectively deliver integrated service for protection of women and children survivors of violence: - The Project supported the authorities to efficiently and effectively implement the normative framework, protocols and procedures, rendering sustainability and national ownership to practices introduced through Project activities. - More than 80 multi-agency groups for cooperation and coordination, composed of the police, social welfare centres and led by the prosecution regularly apply the procedures for processing reported domestic violence cases. This set of procedures was developed within the Project to support the implementation of the Law on Preventing Domestic Violence and adopted by the National Prosecution Office, which referred the procedures to all public prosecution offices in Serbia. - Multi-agency groups for cooperation and coordination and professionals implementing the Law on Preventing Domestic Violence were supported through trainings, hands-on learning and knowledge products to enable professional, effective and efficient support to victims. - The number of reported domestic violence cases recorded during the second year of the implementation of the Law (June 2018 - May 2019) increased:47,583 reported cases processed compared to 44,886 in 2017/2018, 17,954 applications to extend restraining orders submitted by the prosecution compared to 16,185 in 2017/2018,17,300 cases confirmed by the courts compared to 15,617 in 2017/2018. 15,505 individual plans developed compared to 10,503 in 2017/2018. - The new model of work with men who committed domestic violence was developed through a partnership of women’s organizations and programmes for work with perpetrators. This programme, aligned with the standards of the European Network for the Work with Perpetrators of Domestic Violence and the Istanbul Convention, reached out to the victims who were not willing to leave the abusive relationship and were not eager to report violence to institutions, ensuring their safety through work on changing violent behaviour with their abusive partners. - Women from different social and vulnerable groups who experienced violence, were supported and received psychological and legal assistance provided by SOS help lines. - Prejudices against women from vulnerable groups such as the Roma, rural and women with disabilities decreased and obstacles they faced in accessing institutions for protection of domestic violence were acknowledged by professionals. 300 service providers and caseworkers benefited from enhanced knowledge and skills to efficiently deliver integrated services for the protection of women from vulnerable groups, as well as women victims of stalking, sexual violence including rape, forced marriage and sexual harassment. - Multidisciplinary regional health care teams specialized in violence against children were established in four large cities. They serve as regional resource hubs to transfer knowledge to health care workers from surrounding municipalities. The perception of gender-based violence and dominant gender norms changed and increased understanding of women’s and children’s human rights protection mechanisms: - 960 children have benefited from socio-emotional learning, while 624 parents participated in workshops on socio-emotional learning and promotion of diversity. - Almost 6,000 students from primary and secondary schools actively participated in awareness-raising on GBV prevention, as well as in local actions organized to promote diversity and gender equality at the local level. More than 3,000 people were reached by actions of local youth offices that spread messages and values of the Project, messages of gender equality and necessity of preventing gender-based violence. - More than 30 editors and journalists joined the group Journalists against Violence and developed guidelines on how the media should report on violence against women and contributed to increase of ethical and educative media reporting on gender-based violence. The training programmes (curricula) produced under the Project were submitted to the National Institute for Social Protection in order to obtain the accreditation and be used for licensing of service providers and professionals. Upon completion of the accreditation process, both training programmes were included into the Institute’s registry of official programmes, aimed at the capacity building of professionals working within the social protection system, and form part of the standard licence acquisition and maintenance procedure that is mandatory for all professionals in the social protection system. This ensures the sustainability and usage of developed training programmes after the Project is completed.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
